DataElement.preferredName: Metastatic Brain Neoplasm Disease Prognostic Factor Classification Type
DataElement.preferredDefinition: the type or classification of prognostic factors related to the course of brain metastasis and its eventual outcome.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Metastatic Malignant Brain Neoplasm Disease Prognostic Factor Classification
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information relating to the classification or systematic arrangement of general personal and health characteristics that have a bearing on the course of brain metastasis (the spread of a neoplasm from a primary site to the brain) and its eventual outcome.

ObjectClass.preferredName: Metastatic Malignant Neoplasm to the Brain Disease or Disorder
ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: The spread of a neoplasm from a primary site to the brain. The most common primary tumors metastatic to brain include lung cancer(adenosquamous and small cell especially), breast cancer, melanoma, renal cancer and colon cancer. Metastases are frequently found at the grey/white junction. They are usually well demarcated from the brain parenchyma. The majority of metastases (greater than 75%) are found supratentorially with the minority (less than 10%) found in the brainstem. The patients present with signs and symptoms referable to either increased intracranial pressure or focal pathology. A contrast enhanced MRI will give the best view of suspected metastatic cancers. Therapy for the metastatic cancer is based upon the therapy that would be or has been given to the primary cancer. In any event corticosteroids can be useful for reduction of patients' symptoms. (Kaye, Laws Brain Tumors Churchill Livingstone 1995):Any abnormal condition of the body or mind that causes discomfort, dysfunction, or distress to the person affected or those in contact with the person. The term is often used broadly to include injuries, disabilities, syndromes, symptoms, deviant behaviors, and atypical variations of structure and function.

Concepts.longName: Metastatic Malignant Neoplasm in the Brain
Concepts.definition: A malignant neoplasm that has spread to the brain from another anatomic site or system. The majority are carcinomas (usually lung or breast carcinomas).

Any abnormal condition of the body or mind that causes discomfort, dysfunction, or distress to the person affected or those in contact with the person. The term is often used broadly to include injuries, disabilities, syndromes, symptoms, deviant behaviors, and atypical variations of structure and function.
